There are three kinds of karma, namely, bodily karma, verbal karma, and mental karma, as stated in the sÅ«tras.
Some people say:
Bodily actions are called bodily karma, and verbal actions are called verbal karma. These two have both performance and non-performance;
Mental associated actions are called mental karma, and this karma is volition.
Now, what is the mental faculty?
The body and mind all have form and characteristics. What are the characteristics of that which arises from the body?
They are the characteristics of the body's form.
If they are the characteristics of the body's form, why speak of them as bodily actions?
Because they are included in the body as a whole.
The great elements that give rise to the body are called bodily actions. The words in the specific are spoken in the general, just as one says living in the city or living in the forest.
They give rise to that which is grasped.
Why is it so?
It is said that they block the movement of the lips and other features.
That mind does not arise in dependence on the movement of the lips, nor does it arise in dependence on the features, because it arises in dependence on speech.
It does not grasp the previous vow.
That mind does not arise in dependence on the previous vow, but arises due to the causes and conditions of a different retribution.
Why is it so?
It is said that the mind that gives rise to karma arises in the mind of another person, and is known by others.
What are the features?
They are called long and so forth.
What are long and so forth?
It is seeing long and so forth.
To which sense base are they included?
They are included in the form sense base.
Are long and so forth the color of atoms?
Or are they like atoms that gather together?
Or is it a single entity that pervades form and so forth?
If long and so forth are the color of atoms, then long and so forth can be taken bit by bit, just as color is taken bit by bit.
If they are like atoms that gather together, what is the difference between those form atoms and their gathering together?
There is no difference between the atoms and the long one.
If it is a single entity that pervades form and so on, then that single entity would pervade length and so on.
If a single entity pervades each part, it should be perceptible in all places because it exists everywhere.
If it is not a single entity, it should be perceptible in each part. If the Buddha's teachings were destroyed by the aggregation of the ten sense bases and subtle particles,
and if the teachings of Kanada were accomplished by the aggregation of the perception of subtle particles,

then seeing length from one side would give rise to the knowledge of length, seeing short would give rise to the knowledge of short, seeing square would give rise to the knowledge of square, seeing round would give rise to the knowledge of round, seeing protruding would give rise to the knowledge of high, seeing low would give rise to the knowledge of low, seeing level would give rise to the knowledge of level, seeing various sides would give rise to the knowledge of uneven.
Seeing a brocade as it is would give rise to the knowledge of each and every form and so on.
Those different things cannot be seen as one, just like the differences in form.
If one further thinks that all places and all forms and appearances,
this meaning is not so, as such forms and appearances do not exist as different things.
Color is also like this. Abiding in space, one sees long and short, like trees, birds, and ants. The meaning is established without fault.
If it is like this, why is it that in darkness and at a distance one does not see color but sees the collection of shapes?
Why is it that one sees all but does not see the shapes such as trees and so forth?
One sees the collection of those but does not see the shapes. There is no different substance.
In the midst of a collection, in darkness or at a distance, one does not see the two kinds. Although one sees, one is not clear about what it is. What does one see?
Although one sees that color, it is not clear. One should know it like this. This meaning of shape is not established.
Moreover, someone says:
The mind arises in dependence on that, going is called intention.
What is the meaning of arising in dependence on that?
It prevents the movement of the lips and so forth.
Why is it called going?
It is said to be heading towards that direction.
In which sense base is it included?
It is included in the form sense base.
How does one know that it goes towards that direction?
Because it is seen without difference.
Like fire, snow, and bitter wine, the causes and conditions of the sun, etc., enter and then exit, and are not seen to change, but are not without change.
Like the fuel and the burning, the grass, wood, etc., do not see the difference in the flames, but the flames are not without difference.
If at the time of initial entry there is no change, later there will also be no change, because those causes and conditions are not different.
If the firewood, grass, etc., are not of uniform coarseness, the size, brightness, and heat of the flames will all be different.
Because of the different appearances, the meaning of that direction is not appropriate.
If there is no cause of cessation, why is it that the mind and mental factors cannot be obtained?
What are the causes and conditions for the cessation of sound, lamps, etc.?
The rest is also like this.
Why is it that the causes and conditions of their cessation, and the causes and conditions of other dharmas, are not so?
Moreover, just as those dharmas have no causes and conditions, the rest are also like this.
If at the initial entry of grass, wood, etc., into fire, the color is as before and not different, later it will also be like this and there should be no difference.
How can the sounds of lamps, bells, etc., be extinguished and stopped by the initial contact of wind and hand?
This cannot extinguish them, nor can this stop them. If it is like the burning of wood, etc., the extinction of form, etc., and the initial entry and exit, why are they not different?
Because the external conditions are not different, the ripened object should not have subtle, medium, and superior.
How does the initial transformation of the ripened object get transformed?
The conditions are only one, able to produce and able to extinguish. This is not reasonable.
One condition cannot accomplish two dharmas. In this way, there is another cause of extinction in the middle, like the previous abandonment of differences and the continuation of the series.
One should understand in this way. If extinction has a cause, a non-existent dharma has no cause, like the arising of mind, etc.
The dharma of extinction is not accomplished, because all dharmas have causes. Extinction then has no cause.

Like fire, snow, bitter wine, the sun, etc., the causes of ripened transformation, if extinction has a cause, extinction is like form. In this way, the non-existent dharma has the cause of extinction.

Arising also has no cause. Seeing that different dharmas are said to be the cause of the arising of this dharma, the previous mind and the subsequent mind are like the middle of the mind. The transformation of ripening is like milk turning into yogurt, grape juice turning into wine, and wine turning into strong wine. In this way, there is not even a little dharma that abides.
An abiding thing has no activity. Without activity, it abides.
If one sees in this way, what does one see?
One sees the things in this place.
Isn't it seeing the new things in that place?
The new things in that place are seen, like the shadow of burning grass, not the shadow of that place seen here.
Like the sun's abode, in this way the sun is seen turning near and far, the shadow increasing and decreasing as it turns;
the sun in the direction is obscured and not seen.
If someone were to make such a difficult statement:
What things are here?
Those previous things have turned to this direction.
Replying to that person, one would say:
What is this thing? It is explained in the previous meaning. In this way, a thing that abides has no activity.
If a thing has no activity, then it is destroyed by external causes and conditions such as abiding, and later it is seen differently, with each moment being known differently.
If it is not known differently, then that thing is not distinct;
knowing it is not that thing, why not say it is different?
In this way, these two kinds are both invisible, and in this way the meaning of going and coming is not established.
In reality there is no going and coming.

The essence of conditioned phenomena is self-destructed in each moment. In the present moment, the cause of arising gives rise to the mind as the cause. The movement of the hands and feet can be said to be the intention of going.
The disciple of the rising sun makes the following statement:
In which sense base is it included?
It is included in the form sense base.
Why is that?
What the eye does not see, such as blue and other colors, if others can see it, it can be said to be the intention, but if others do not see it, how can it be said to be the intention?
How is it known to exist?
How does the wind element arise in different places in the body, causing movement?
This wind element moves, which is called arising due to conditions in other places.
How is it?
Grass and leaves follow the wind element and move, and so does action.
Arising in other places, the power of action is not established, so what need is there to discriminate?
The cause of the arising of such a body is the wind element born from the mind, which is called intention.
How is it that what is not intention can be called intention?
According to the Dharma of the ÅšÄkyas, contact is neither good nor not good. Such a mind arises in a body in another place, and this arising is called intention.
If it is so, then intention is only a form and has no real substance, while the body has many parts.
Intention is also not intention, and taste, etc. are of another person.
According to the Dharma of the ÅšÄkyas, taste, etc. are neither good nor not good, because the mind gives rise to form, and it can be called intention.
It is not that the mind gives rise to it, but the wind element itself gives rise to it.
According to the Dharma of the ÅšÄkyas, the form element is neither good nor not good.
The form that arises in that place cannot be obtained by the mind.
If there is an offering to the gods, if that thing does not exist, the gods cannot give it, then it cannot be obtained.
There is no difference in the creation of things, who can create a difference?
That which cannot be obtained like this form and so on, like the eye can see, birth is not like this.
Since it cannot be seen, how can it be said to be the mind?
This has already been said, like birth is not like this, form has also been said.
There is only non-action, which is the action of the body.
What is called non-action?
It is the form included in the dharma realm, such as fear and so on.
How can non-action be said to be non-action?
If it is in the desire realm and turns together with the mind, then it is known to be in the form realm, which is different from the mind.
And when there is no mind, fear and fearlessness are lost together with the mind. If it is received, the power is always not lost later.
In the precepts, it is said:
How can a monk who is silent lie?
Moreover, indeterminate karma cannot be accomplished.
Non-action is of two kinds, namely wholesome and unwholesome.
In that instant, non-action arises together, just like the discrimination of bodily and verbal actions. If they are both wholesome and unwholesome, they are both not established.
Why is this?
If one abandons the body, it is cut off, and in the future world, the loved and unloved fruits cannot be obtained.
Moreover, some people say:
Why is past karma not established?
If past karma obtains the loved and unloved two kinds of fruits in the future world, then it is like a boil on a boil.
Past karma that exists in the past is called having a front but no back.
If the TathÄgata says:
Even if one passes through a hundred kalpas, karma is always not lost,
Obtaining the combination of causes and conditions, at that time the fruits and retributions ripen.
What about this verse?
Being able to give fruits and retributions is the meaning of not being lost.
Thus, the first half of the verse has been explained. Who does not believe that the fruits are obtained after a long time?
What is the meaning of obtaining the fruit?
If the continuity transforms like a rice seed, if it abides in its own characteristics, it should be understood in this way.
If abiding in its own characteristics can give rise to the fruit, then it would not be destroyed and should always give rise to the fruit.
Since it has no self-characteristics, it is called destruction.
Moreover, it is not like this: having acted, one does not act again.
How does one not act?
The fruit is not given again.
Why is it not given?
Because it has already been given.
It cannot be given again after having been given, just as a thing that has already arisen does not arise again.
Why is the homogeneous fruit not given again?
How is it that the retribution is all completely given? The causes and conditions of the arising dharma do not have such power.
A person who has exhausted defilements does not give rise to the fruit of retribution in the subsequent moment of having exhausted defilements. How can it be said to cease at a later time?

It does not have such power to be able to give rise to the fruit of retribution. If the seed-cause has power over the fruit, it can be said that the power of the cause can give rise to the fruit of retribution.
If there are people who have past [karma], then they will have future [karma]. Why does the future not give rise to karmic retribution?
At all times, what is it that exists?
At what time does it not exist?
They say like this:
If it obtains union, then the karmic retribution ripens.
This is not so.
If a person's power, at what time is it powerful, and what is the power of this thing? This person and this fruit will ultimately not be accomplished.
There is past karma, and in the future world, one who obtains karmic retribution will not accomplish this.
Moreover, some people say:

That good and bad bodily and verbal karma, in the continuity of the aggregates, is apart from the mind, and is perfumed by dharmas. If it is called accumulation or non-loss, then in the next world one will obtain loved or unloved fruits.
If the mental karma is different from the arising and ceasing of the mind, or if it does not perfume the mind, how can one obtain karmic retribution in the next world?
If a person reads and recites, they will remember for a long time.
They see such things, and those who practice like this.
By what dharmas is it perfumed?
If one recollects what things?
When one sees recitation and so forth, where does the mind of recollection arise later?
In the samÄdhi of cessation, when the initial mind is extinguished, where does the mind arise later?
Like purple mineral juice staining the flowers of the madhuka tree, the two are extinguished together.
In this way, what thing in the middle stains the fruit, causing the red pulp to arise later?

In the Dharma, hearing and contemplation are also like this. The power of the continuity of the mind and the power of perfuming transform, and in the next life one obtains the fruit. One should understand it like this.
Like purple mineral juice staining the flowers of the madhuka tree, the red pulp in the fruit.
The body's karma is like this. Because the continuity perfumes the mind, therefore one cannot obtain such a mind that opposes good and evil.
If this person creates good or evil, then this person's loved or unloved fruit is in accord with the power, not in accord with a different characteristic.

If karma ceases and the mind continues, resulting in fruits in the next world, how can there be a mindless cessation samÄdhi and a mind of non-perception where the mind is cut off, and the fruits of past karma arise in that very body later on?
Some say:
It is imprinted on the mind continuum and obtained.
Where does that cessation samÄdhi continue?
The initial cause of samÄpatti.
How can it be long extinguished?
How can it be a cause?
I have already said that past fruits are obtained. Where does this arise in the mind in between?
Some say:
The seeds of the form faculties are obtained in those seeds.
The seeds of mind and mental factors are supported in two places, namely in the mind body and in the form faculty body.
In this way, the mind takes dharmas as conditions and produces mental consciousness.
In the middle, there is no mind. How can it arise?
There is also the expression of obtaining seeds. The characteristics of the mind should be understood in this way. The cause is spoken of as the fruit, like hunger and thirst.
How can mental and mental factors all have two kinds of seeds?
There are no two kinds of sprouts in one seed.
One does not see multiple births in one cause and condition, and the error is also like this.
In the samÄdhi of no-mind and the cessation of thought, how can the results of karma be obtained later?
This is one box of errors.
What is the box of errors?
For those who have the samÄdhi of no-mind,
Some people say:
There is the samÄdhi of mind. If in the assembly of five hundred arhats of the VibhÄá¹£Ä, the great virtue of Vasumitra says:
For those who have the cessation of mind, they have this error. Because my cessation samÄdhi has mind.
Citing the sÅ«tras as evidence, he says:
Bodily activity then ceases, the faculties do not change, and consciousness does not leave the body.
Moreover, what consciousness does that person believe in?ğŸ”½Some people say:
The mental consciousness.

The Buddha said that the mind consciousness arises from the causes and conditions of the mind, and the combination of the three is called contact, which arises together with feeling, conception, volition, and so forth.
How can there be a mind consciousness that is not the combination of the three things?
There may be a combination that is not contact,
or there may be contact that is not feeling or conception.
If it is said that the cessation of feeling and conception is the cessation of everything, why did the TathÄgata say in the sÅ«tras:
All feelings are conditioned by craving.
Not all feelings are conditioned by craving, and the same should be said for contact.
Not all contact is conditioned by feeling, and the TathÄgata also explained the meaning differently in the sÅ«tras.
Ignorance gives rise to contact, contact gives rise to feeling, and feeling is the condition for craving. Nowhere is it said that contact is separate from feeling and conception.
If this is not explained, then the error would be established, and it cannot be denied that the combination of the three things is called contact.
Without those three things, feeling and conception do not arise.
If it were not so, there would be no contact in samÄdhi, let alone feeling and conceptualization.
Some people say:
There is only one mental consciousness.
What kind of consciousness is it?
Is it wholesome, defiled, or indeterminate?
This meaning is now explained.
If it is wholesome, then it is associated with the roots of wholesomeness such as non-greed, and how can there be no contact in wholesomeness without non-greed, etc.?

If it is wholesome at that time, then the power of causes and conditions, if it is wholesome, is not separate from the mind of wholesomeness, etc., and the power of the mind of wholesomeness, etc., is the cause of the arising of the three kinds of minds.
If it is defiled, how is it not associated with afflictions?
If it is defiled by afflictions, how can there be no contact?
Moreover, the TathÄgata spoke of this in the DaÅ›ottara SÅ«tra:
If there is a form aggregate, feeling aggregate, perception aggregate, or formation aggregate, all those aggregates are conditioned by contact.
Even the attainment of non-perception is still undefiled, let alone the attainment of cessation.
If it is indeed undefiled and indeterminate, what is it then?
Is it born of retribution, deportment, craftsmanship, or transformation?
Now we should ask them:

If it is born of retribution, how can the mind of samÄdhi at the peak of existence descend to the eighth stage, with an intervening gap, and the consciousness of retribution in the desire realm continue with the mind?
In this way, there is also the arising of an immovable mind. How does it continue?
As in the MahÄkauá¹£á¹­hila SÅ«tra, where he asks the TathÄgata:
How many contacts does one experience in the samÄdhi of cessation?
The TathÄgata answers:
Kauá¹£á¹­hila,
one experiences three contacts, namely, the immovable, the signless, and the inexistent.
Previously, by the power of resolve, one enters the samÄdhi of cessation. The previous mind resolves not to arise beyond the time.
What is the meaning of this?
How are they all conditions?
The samÄdhi of cessation ends with the mind at the peak of existence. Previously, the mind perfumed by karma in the desire realm receives retribution.
Why is it not the previous mind that receives retribution?
Why is it so?
If the previous retribution form is cut off and does not continue, how can the subsequent mind continue?
If it is the same for deportment, etc., how can the mind be conditioned by deportment, etc. without contact?
The nine successive concentrations and eight liberations that are conditioned good are not appropriate, and the defiled mind and indeterminate mind do not continue.

The samadhi of the peak of existence relies on the concentration of cessation, recollection, and the perception of the cessation of ideation and sensation. If there is a mind-consciousness in entering the concentration of cessation, what does it perceive?
If it perceives the concentration of cessation, how can it not be good?
If it is good, then it is associated with non-greed.
If it is associated, how can it not be the cause and condition of contact?
If it enters the concentration of cessation with a different perception, how can it be associated with a confused mind in the middle, and its own mind discriminates it as indeterminate?
Both of these are not appropriate, and thus one does not know the true meaning of the scriptures.
That master of treatises then says with joy:
In the samÄdhi of cessation, there is still mental consciousness that makes such distinctions.
How can that be a samÄdhi with mind?
As the master of the sÅ«tras believes and explains.
How does the master of the sÅ«tras believe and explain?

He explains that the retributive consciousness, with all its seeds, is secretly bound by karmic activity, which is uninterrupted. In the various places of rebirth, the characteristics of the retributive consciousness are destroyed, yet it continues to function, up to and including nirvÄá¹‡a, without being severed.
If it is like this, it can be said to have a mind that is different from the six consciousnesses, and therefore does not turn.
When first entering the samÄdhi of cessation, the power of the mind increases, and at that time the seeds are all hidden and closed, and therefore it is called without mind.
There are two kinds of mind:
The first is the mind that accumulates all seeds, and the second is the mind that destroys various objects of cognition.
Because it is separated from the second mind, it is called mindless, just as a bed with one leg is called legless because it lacks the other legs.

The seeds are closed, and the consciousness of retribution turns with softness, middling, and upper, like water, heat, and the force of shooting arrows, from this to that. The seeds of consciousness reach their limit and are born again, following various causes and conditions at a later time.
The various seeds are stored in the consciousness of retribution.
The different consciousnesses arise together with the dharmas, and the good and bad perfuming follows the power of the seeds in that order, if the continuity turns.
According to the power of that perfuming, one will obtain the loved and unloved fruits in the future body.
This consciousness is the cause and condition, and therefore it is said:ğŸ”½This mind consciousness seed,
continuously flowing without end,
arises from the power of various seeds in the mind itself and its causes and conditions.
That order is not lost, and when the time comes, the fruit is obtained,
just like the fragrance of mÄdana and the color of the flower when the flower is dyed.
The meaning of this is as stated in a verse in the MahÄyÄna sÅ«tra Profound Secret Liberation:
The seeds of the Älaya consciousness are subtle, deep, and flowing like a current,
Not spoken of for foolish people, fearing they will discriminate a self.
What is the meaning of this verse?
It further has a secret bondage that grasps the body, therefore it is called the Älaya consciousness;
It is the basis for the seeds of all dharmas, therefore it is called the Älaya consciousness;
The retribution from past karma is called the consciousness of retribution.
If there were no such consciousness, by what is the body cognized?
Until the body is exhausted, it is not separated from the body, and there is no other consciousness.
If there is no other [consciousness], what object is the fundamental antidote to afflictions?
How can the root of afflictions be antidoted?
Because there are no two dharmas.
The continuity of defiled, wholesome, and pure mental activities is birth in the formless realm.
What are those activities?
On what object does it depend?
If so, then non-retribution should also be able to function, but that is not appropriate.

For example, a person who has cultivated the peak of existence and attained the state of anÄgÄmin who has exhausted defilements, if the uncontaminated mind of the sphere of nothingness appears, what is the self that does not regress from the peak of existence?
The combination of various factors is called the life faculty, there is no separate substance.
Those dharmas only have the power of transformation similar to the aggregate of retribution, not a separate substance.
The power of similarity is like the power of similarity in rice stalks, it should be understood in this way. There is another consciousness, like the statement that there is consciousness.
What is its object?
It has an undetermined object.
Why is it said that consciousness has an undetermined object, and again that it is different from consciousness like in the samÄdhi of cessation?
As the Venerable TÄmraÅ›ÄtÄ«ya says there is a consciousness with a portion, and some people say it is the fundamental consciousness.
To which aggregate is it included?
This meaning is included in the aggregate of consciousness.
How does this sÅ«tra text explain it?
Which consciousnesses grasp the aggregates?
It refers to the six groups of consciousnesses.
As for the condition of consciousness in relation to formations, what is consciousness?
It is the six groups of consciousnesses.
Remembering this teaching, it is like the aggregate of formations.
What is the aggregate of formations?
It is the six groups of intentions.
Not subsuming other dharmas, what else is there to remember?
In the profound and secret liberation sutras, the Tathagata has all said:
I do not speak of the self for foolish ordinary beings, fearing they will discriminate the self.
For what other reason is there such discrimination?
Those conditioned formations revolve everywhere, fearing people do not know.
If it is said in this way, relying on various objects of cognition, the superior mind of supreme understanding.
If those afflictions correspond to the antidote, the seeds of defilement and purity are spoken of.
If the result is spoken of in this way, inferring such consciousness, but not speaking of the causal consciousness, that is upside-down speech.
For this reason, there is this consciousness of the body.

Moreover, the existence of body consciousness can be explained in the same way as the above sequence. This meaning is consistent, not because it is consistent with the meaning explained in all sÅ«tras. It is not like this in all sÅ«tras.
Do not think that because it is not explained in all sÅ«tras, the Älaya consciousness does not exist.
These two kinds of mind and consciousness flow together in one place, namely the retributive consciousness and the discriminating consciousness.
If this is so, what faults are there?
If there are two kinds of consciousnesses that continue in this way, then there should be two sentient beings, like the consciousness in the body.

It cannot be like this, because the seeds and their fruits are not in a mutually corresponding state of transformation. The retributive consciousness flows and can perfume the discriminating consciousness, but the body consciousness is not like this in the middle.
If this is so, then there is no fault.

Moreover, there is the view of the destruction of seeds and what is produced from seeds, which is different from the roots and what is produced from the roots of Å›Älu rice and blue lotus flowers, whether seen or unseen. It is not like this.
If it is explained in this way, there is no fault. In this way, the Älaya consciousness truly exists.
Why do the six consciousnesses not rely on the self? What is the consciousness that is obtained?
If it is like the Älaya consciousness, which continues as the cause and conditions for transformation, what is the difference between them?
If it is one and ultimately unmoving, how can the consciousnesses and so forth be perfumed?
Like the purple mineral juice perfumes the mÄndÄrava tree and flowers.
If there is no perfuming, there is no superior transformation. How can one know in advance, like cultivating desires and so forth, and remember desires and so forth for a long time?
Without mind in the self, where does the mind arise later?
If there is no self, what power does the mind have to rely on that self and discriminate?
If there is a self, how does that mind arise in sequence?
If it is the power of the different births with common causes and conditions, how can it be known?
If it is the power of that which gives rise to the turning of abiding mindfulness, what is this dharma?
If so, dissimilar things would depend on each other, contradicting the teachings of the sÅ«tras that all dharmas are without self.

Thus, the self conceived and imagined by one's own mind perfumes the Älaya consciousness, causing it to continue without interruption, and the meaning of attaining a later body and its fruits is then accomplished, not like the body and speech karma as described.
Moreover, such body and speech karma do not contradict the sÅ«tras' teaching of the three kinds of karma.
What is the meaning of this?
This meaning does not contradict what the TathÄgata taught, and thus is faultless.
How is it that this teaching is faultless?
The meaning of this is now explained.
For what meaning is the threefold karma taught?
What is the body?
What is karma?
What is the meaning of body?
What is the meaning of karma?
What is bodily karma?
The same should be said of verbal karma.
For what meaning is the karma of the body, etc. taught, and not the karma of the eye, etc.?
For what meaning does one expound such meaning?

The ten good karmic paths are shown to be subsumed in the three karmas. Speaking of many is for fear that people will learn the three kinds of precepts like the son of Vá¹›ji, and for them to expound the three kinds that are done by the body, not by mouth or mind, and only to distinguish one.

Again, for other people, the characteristics of bodily karma are expounded. The body is also subsumed in the sense faculties and the great elements, and is called bodily karma because it is a collection of thoughts, meaning a collection of the great elements and subtle particles that make up the great elements.
Some people say:
The impure is called the body, because it is a collection of impure things.
The bodies of gods and humans cannot be called bodies.
Mental activity is called mental karma, and bodily movement and collected karma are called bodily karma.
There are three kinds of thoughts, namely deliberation, determination, and progress.
If one moves the body, the continuity of that body will give rise to causes in the middle, and it will be blown by the wind element, which is called bodily karma.
Excluding the middle phrase, like sÄla oil or like wind dust, it explains the three karmic paths of killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct.
How can it be said that they are included in the body?
